results.title: Children's Theatre
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Children at the Studio Theatre in Adelaide study painting, music and speech as part of their training in ballet. This is a Children’s Theatre for children and by children. Classes and rehearsals, planning and teaching precede the performance of an Australian ballet, telling the story of an Australian aboriginal legend.

results.title: The Cattle carters
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, Cinesound for British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A dramatic account of road trains in outback Australia. Each year thousands of cattle are moved from the great cattle properties of north-west Australia to the railhead for shipment to southern and overseas markets. Today this journey is carried out as a round-the-clock enterprise operating 48 ton road trains over the tracks where drovers once rode for weeks at a time. Typical is the trail from Anna Plains to Meekatharra - the longest overland road haul of its type in Australia. (Diploma of Merit, 1962 Melbourne Film Festival).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek Williams, Cinesound for British Petroleum and Greenpark Productions

results.title: Beyond the boom: metal mining in Australia
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle, Australian Mining Industry Council and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The evolution of mining in Australia from the first gold discoveries to the iron, nickel and copper developments of the 1960’s , its historic importance in national growth and economic stability and in the exploration and settling of much of Australia. The scope of modern mining and processing industries, exploration and prospecting, the growth of new towns and stimulation of regional development.

results.title: Australian by design
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The manufacture of Australia’s own car from the initial design on a drawing board to the completed vehicle as it comes off the assembly line. Precedence is given to safety in both design and engineering. Rigorous tests are carried out at Lang Lang testing track which incorporates all types of road conditions. In creating an automotive industry G.M.H. has stimulated the nation’s industries and economy.

results.title: Anzac
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Historical photographs and early newsreels tell the story of the Gallipoli assault; embarkation and transport of 75,000 men in 200 ships from Egypt to Gallipoli; initial landing below cliffs; building a jetty and digging in; main British attack at Cape Helles and subsequent assaults on the heights; hardships, casualties and final evacuation. Commentary by Moray Powell and Peter Carver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films

results.title: Amy
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Amy is a 16 year-old aboriginal girl from the country now living in Sydney. She faces many problems at school, in getting a job, and in the community because of her colour. Photography by Dean Semler.

results.title: Aborigines in the Alice
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Looks at two problems facing aborigines in Alice Springs - child care and alcoholism. In 1970 the death rate among Aboriginal children rose to nearly 1 in 5, one of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. Today the ratio has improved, but Aboriginal health still presents a grim picture. Interviews people concerned. Reporter: Brian King; Photographer: Richard Bailie-Mace; Sound: Peter Lipscomb.

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.
results.description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.

results.title: Payback
results.creator_credit: Penny McDonald, Warwick Thornton and Blackfella Films
results.brief_description: Paddy, an old aboriginal man, has been in jail for twenty years. It is the day of his release. Paddy knows of two laws - white law and black law. The twenty years he has spent doing time for the white man’s law has been in preparation for this one - his payback day.
